segment.source: Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services (Windows 10)
segment.target: Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services (Windows 10)

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services security policy setting.

segment.source: Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services
segment.target: Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services

segment.source: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services security policy setting.
segment.target: Describes the best practices, location, values, policy management, and security considerations for the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services security policy setting.

segment.source: This policy setting determines which users or groups can access the logon screen of a remote device through a Remote Desktop Services connection.
segment.target: This policy setting determines which users or groups can access the logon screen of a remote device through a Remote Desktop Services connection.

segment.source: It is possible for a user to establish a Remote Desktop Services connection to a particular server but not be able to log on to the console of that same server.
segment.target: It is possible for a user to establish a Remote Desktop Services connection to a particular server but not be able to log on to the console of that same server.

segment.source: To control who can open a Remote Desktop Services connection and log on to the device, add users to or remove users from the Remote Desktop Users group.
segment.target: To control who can open a Remote Desktop Services connection and log on to the device, add users to or remove users from the Remote Desktop Users group.

segment.source: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment
segment.target: Computer ConfigurationWindows SettingsSecurity SettingsLocal PoliciesUser Rights Assignment

segment.source: By default, members of the Administrators group have this right on domain controllers, workstations, and servers.
segment.target: By default, members of the Administrators group have this right on domain controllers, workstations, and servers.

segment.source: The Remote Desktops Users group also has this right on workstations and servers.
segment.target: The Remote Desktops Users group also has this right on workstations and servers.

segment.source: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.
segment.target: The following table lists the actual and effective default policy values.

segment.source: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.
segment.target: Default values are also listed on the policy’s property page.

segment.source: This section describes different features and tools available to help you manage this policy.
segment.target: This section describes different features and tools available to help you manage this policy.

segment.source: To use Remote Desktop Services to successfully log on to a remote device, the user or group must be a member of the Remote Desktop Users or Administrators group and be granted the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services right.
segment.target: To use Remote Desktop Services to successfully log on to a remote device, the user or group must be a member of the Remote Desktop Users or Administrators group and be granted the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services right.

segment.source: It is possible for a user to establish an Remote Desktop Services session to a particular server, but not be able to log on to the console of that same server.
segment.target: It is possible for a user to establish an Remote Desktop Services session to a particular server, but not be able to log on to the console of that same server.

segment.source: To exclude users or groups, you can assign the Deny log on through Remote Desktop Services user right to those users or groups.
segment.target: To exclude users or groups, you can assign the Deny log on through Remote Desktop Services user right to those users or groups.

segment.source: However, be careful when you use this method because you could create conflicts for legitimate users or groups that have been allowed access through the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right.
segment.target: However, be careful when you use this method because you could create conflicts for legitimate users or groups that have been allowed access through the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right.

segment.source: For more information, see Deny log on through Remote Desktop Services.
segment.target: For more information, see Deny log on through Remote Desktop Services.

segment.source: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.
segment.target: A restart of the device is not required for this policy setting to be effective.

segment.source: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.
segment.target: Any change to the user rights assignment for an account becomes effective the next time the owner of the account logs on.

segment.source: Group Policy settings are applied through GPOs in the following order, which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:
segment.target: Group Policy settings are applied through GPOs in the following order, which will overwrite settings on the local computer at the next Group Policy update:

segment.source: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.
segment.target: This section describes how an attacker might exploit a feature or its configuration, how to implement the countermeasure, and the possible negative consequences of countermeasure implementation.

segment.source: Any account with the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right can log on to the remote console of the device.
segment.target: Any account with the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right can log on to the remote console of the device.

segment.source: If you do not restrict this user right to legitimate users who must log on to the console of the computer, unauthorized users could download and run malicious software to elevate their privileges.
segment.target: If you do not restrict this user right to legitimate users who must log on to the console of the computer, unauthorized users could download and run malicious software to elevate their privileges.

segment.source: For domain controllers, assign the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right only to the Administrators group.
segment.target: For domain controllers, assign the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right only to the Administrators group.

segment.source: For other server roles and devices, add the Remote Desktop Users group.
segment.target: For other server roles and devices, add the Remote Desktop Users group.

segment.source: For servers that have the Remote Desktop (RD) Session Host role service enabled and do not run in Application Server mode, ensure that only authorized IT personnel who must manage the computers remotely belong to these groups.
segment.target: For servers that have the Remote Desktop (RD) Session Host role service enabled and do not run in Application Server mode, ensure that only authorized IT personnel who must manage the computers remotely belong to these groups.

segment.source: Caution: For RD Session Host servers that run in Application Server mode, ensure that only users who require access to the server have accounts that belong to the Remote Desktop Users group because this built-in group has this logon right by default.
segment.target: Caution: For RD Session Host servers that run in Application Server mode, ensure that only users who require access to the server have accounts that belong to the Remote Desktop Users group because this built-in group has this logon right by default.

segment.source: Alternatively, you can assign the Deny log on through Remote Desktop Services user right to groups such as Account Operators, Server Operators, and Guests.
segment.target: Alternatively, you can assign the Deny log on through Remote Desktop Services user right to groups such as Account Operators, Server Operators, and Guests.

segment.source: However, be careful when you use this method because you could block access to legitimate administrators who also belong to a group that has the Deny log on through Remote Desktop Services user right.
segment.target: However, be careful when you use this method because you could block access to legitimate administrators who also belong to a group that has the Deny log on through Remote Desktop Services user right.

segment.source: Removal of the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right from other groups (or membership changes in these default groups) could limit the abilities of users who perform specific administrative roles in your environment.
segment.target: Removal of the Allow log on through Remote Desktop Services user right from other groups (or membership changes in these default groups) could limit the abilities of users who perform specific administrative roles in your environment.

segment.source: You should confirm that delegated activities are not adversely affected.
segment.target: You should confirm that delegated activities are not adversely affected.
